values.description:
This pull request creates the initial version of the documentation. The documentation is hosted in the [readthedocs](https://readthedocs.org/) server and updates are automatically triggered every time we push a change in our repository.

You can check the documentation here:

http://ignition-transport.readthedocs.org/

There are quite a few more details that I'd like to add to the documentation but I feel this is a good enough starting point for a first pull request.

values.title: Improve the behavior of TopicList and ServiceList

summary.html:
Here's a problem:

When you want to use mynode.TopicList() or node.ServiceList() you can be in one of these two scenarios, assuming that are existing nodes on the network running on different processes:

  • mynode's process has just started. For example, this is the case when you execute ign topic -l (ign-tools required). In this scenario, your discovery needs some time to receive the heartbeats from the rest of the nodes. This means that you needed to wait some time before calling TopicList() or ServiceList(), otherwise the list of topics/services would be empty most of the time.
ignition::transport::Node mynode;
std::this_thread::sleep_for(std::chrono::milliseconds(someTime));
std::vector<std::string> topics;
node.TopicList(topics);
  • mynode's process has been running for a while and your discovery has a good picture of the other nodes on the network. In this case there was no need to wait if you wanted to call TopicList() or ServiceList().
ignition::transport::Node mynode;
std::vector<std::string> topics;
node.TopicList(topics);

Before this pull request, Ignition Transport was not helping to differentiate in which situation you were. This pull request makes the behavior of TopicList() or ServiceList() slightly different depending on the state of the discovery layer. If the discovery is starting, TopicList() and ServiceList() will block until the discovery is ready, to make sure that we have picture of the network before answering. If the discovery layer has been initialized, the functions won't block.

CI results:

  • Trusty is happy.
  • Homebrew is happy.
  • Windows is pending.

values.description:
There's a potential deadlock in the following scenario (numbers show the order of execution):

* Thread1 (userland):
  
```
#!c++

 Node::Publish() (1)
   acquire NodeShared mutex (2)
   Discovery::DiscoveryMsgInfo() (6)
     acquire Discovery mutex (7 - Wait)
```

* Thread2 (Discovery):

```
#!c++

 RecvDiscoveryUpdate() (3)
   DispatchDiscoveryMsg() (4)
     acquire Discovery mutex (5)
       NodeShared::OnNewSrvConnection() (8)
         acquire NodeShared mutex (9 - Deadlock!)
```

This pull request modifies `Publish()` for acquiring NodeShared and Discovery mutexes at the same time:

* Thread1 (userland):
  
```
#!c++

 Node::Publish() (1)
   acquire NodeShared mutex and Discovery (2)
   Discovery::DiscoveryMsgInfo() (6-Release mutexes)
```

* Thread2 (Discovery):

```
#!c++

 RecvDiscoveryUpdate() (3)
   DispatchDiscoveryMsg() (4)
     acquire Discovery mutex (5 - Wait)
       NodeShared::OnNewSrvConnection() (7)
         acquire NodeShared mutex (8)
```

CI results:

* Trusty is [happy](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/47/).
* Homebrew is [pending](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/47/).
* Windows is [happy](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/89/).

values.description:
The `ignition-tools` commands don't work on OS X because the library name is hard-coded with a `.so` suffix, while `.dylib` is used on OS X.

I tried to figure out how to automatically identify the library file name using the following:

~~~
get_target_property(IGN_LIBRARY_NAME ${PROJECT_NAME_LOWER}${PROJECT_MAJOR_VERSION} LOCATION)
~~~

That gives the full path, which could be stripped out, but that variable name isn't recommended:

~~~
CMake Warning (dev) at src/cmd/CMakeLists.txt:6 (get_target_property):
  Policy CMP0026 is not set: Disallow use of the LOCATION target property.
  Run "cmake --help-policy CMP0026" for policy details.  Use the cmake_policy
  command to set the policy and suppress this warning.

  The LOCATION property should not be read from target "ignition-transport1".
  Use the target name directly with add_custom_command, or use the generator
  expression $<TARGET_FILE>, as appropriate.
~~~

Apparently `configure_file` occurs before the generator stage, which is when the library name is generated. I wasn't sure how to do this in the generator stage, so I've just done this instead.
values.title: Use dylib suffix on APPLE platforms instead of so

values.description:
We were not checking the return value of `zmq::poll()`. This might cause an uncaught exception in the following scenario:

We are waiting in a blocking function such as `poll()`. When a signal is received, some operating systems return from `poll()` and set `errno` to `EINTR`. In the case of the zmq c++ wrapper that we use, an exception is triggered. 

We discovered this while running a QT example. You can compile this code and try it without/with this pull request.

https://bitbucket.org/snippets/ignitionrobotics/gK6gd

CI results:

* Trusty is [pending](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/50/).
* Homebrew is [pending](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/44/).
* Windows is [pending](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/92/).

values.description:
New `waitForShutdown()` function that can be used to block the current thread and wait for events. The examples `requester_async`, `responser` and `subscriber` use this function instead of `getchar()`. 

`waitForShutdown` installs a signal handler that captures `SIGINT` and `SIGTERM` and exits after any of these signals are received. This change makes the examples robust to `CTRL-C`, whereas before it could segfault on Windows, as the program was not tearing down properly. 

Note that it's not mandatory to use this function. It's just an option when you want to block the main thread and wait until the user hits `CTRL-C`. The `publisher` example still shows an alternative use case, where the user captures `SIGINT`/`SIGTERM` and triggers the termination of the program.

CI results:

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/84/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/84/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/173/) :large_blue_circle:

values.description:
A `disconnect()` call on a `zmq` socket can raise an ~~exception~~ assertion if the other side of the connection is already destroyed. This might happen if you have a fast publisher that publishes some data and then is destroyed right away.

How to test the patch?

* Compile this branch.
* Execute the following test a couple of times. It should **not** fail: 

```
#!c++

./test/integration/INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPubSub --gtest_filter=*FastPublisher*
```

* Save the test:

```
#!c++

cp ./test/integration/INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPubSub ~
```

* Compile  `ign-transport1` branch to reproduce the problem.
* Execute the test that you saved before a couple of times and it should eventually fail with an internal zmq assertion: 

```
#!c++

~/INTEGRATION_twoProcessesPubSub --gtest_filter=*FastPublisher*
```

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/93/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/87/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/177/) :large_blue_circle:

values.description:
All Ignition Transport functions that use callbacks accept one of these alternatives:

* A free function.
* A member function.
* A lambda.

With the previous version of the code, `Request()` combined with a member function didn't compile. This pull request fixes the problem.

There are a few style changes too.

values.description:
If [ignition-tools](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-tools) is installed, the test `tools/UNIT_IGN_TEST` is executed. This test verifies the transport command line utilities (e.g. `ign topic -l`).

`ign` parses a set of yaml files to find the list of subcommands that are available. As an example, ignition transport makes available the subcommands `topic` and `service`. The yaml configuration file also contains the path to a ruby script that parses and executes the subcommand specified. Here's an example of the `transport1.yaml` that is installed in my machine with ignition transport:

```
#!c++

--- # Subcommands available inside ignition-transport.
format: 1.0.0
library_name: ignition-transport
library_version: 1.1.0
library_path: /home/caguero/local/lib/ruby/ignition/cmdtransport1
commands:
    - topic   : Print information about topics.
    - service : Print information about services.
```

Before this pull request, running `tools/UNIT_IGN_TEST` without doing `make install` was not working properly, as the value of `library_path` inside `transport1.rb` was pointing to the installed `cmdtransport1.rb` instead of pointing to the recently compiled version available only under the `build` directory. This pull request solves this problem.

We now create two versions of `transport1.yaml`, one for internal testing and the other for installation. The internal testing version has a `library_path` pointing to the `cmdtransport1.rb` version under `build`:


```
#!c++

--- # Subcommands available inside ignition-transport.
format: 1.0.0
library_name: ignition-transport
library_version: 1.1.0
library_path: /data/ign-transport/build/src/cmd/cmdtransport1
commands:
    - topic   : Print information about topics.
    - service : Print information about services.
---
```

It also fixes a problem in Mac OS X running some test:


```
#!c++

libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type std::__1::system_error: recursive_mutex lock failed: Invalid argument
```

I believe this was caused by the destruction of some NodeShared member variables before destructing the `Discovery` object. If Discovery triggers a NodeShared callback during the destruction phase, some member (mutex) might be already destroyed.

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-trusty-amd64/96/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/90/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/183/) :large_blue_circle:
values.title: ign_TEST without make install

ign parses a set of yaml files to find the list of subcommands that are available. As an example, ignition transport makes available the subcommands topic and service. The yaml configuration file also contains the path to a ruby script that parses and executes the subcommand specified. Here's an example of the transport1.yaml that is installed in my machine with ignition transport:

--- # Subcommands available inside ignition-transport.
format: 1.0.0
library_name: ignition-transport
library_version: 1.1.0
library_path: /home/caguero/local/lib/ruby/ignition/cmdtransport1
commands:
    - topic   : Print information about topics.
    - service : Print information about services.

Before this pull request, running tools/UNIT_IGN_TEST without doing make install was not working properly, as the value of library_path inside transport1.rb was pointing to the installed cmdtransport1.rb instead of pointing to the recently compiled version available only under the build directory. This pull request solves this problem.

We now create two versions of transport1.yaml, one for internal testing and the other for installation. The internal testing version has a library_path pointing to the cmdtransport1.rb version under build:

--- # Subcommands available inside ignition-transport.
format: 1.0.0
library_name: ignition-transport
library_version: 1.1.0
library_path: /data/ign-transport/build/src/cmd/cmdtransport1
commands:
    - topic   : Print information about topics.
    - service : Print information about services.
---

It also fixes a problem in Mac OS X running some test:

libc++abi.dylib: terminating with uncaught exception of type std::__1::system_error: recursive_mutex lock failed: Invalid argument

I believe this was caused by the destruction of some NodeShared member variables before destructing the Discovery object. If Discovery triggers a NodeShared callback during the destruction phase, some member (mutex) might be already destroyed.

  • Trusty :large_blue_circle:
  • Homebrew :large_blue_circle:
  • Windows :large_blue_circle:

values.title: Node::Advertise return object

summary.html:
This augments the Node API to make it a bit easier/cleaner to advertise and publish messages.

The current pattern relies on keeping track of std::string topic names for each advertised topic. For example:

std::string myTopic = "/my/topic";
node.Advertise<msg_type>(myTopic);
node.Publish(myTopic, myMsg);

This gets a bit more cumbersome if you want to do something like this:

std::string topicBase = "/part_a";
node.Advertise<type>(topicBase + "/torque");
node.Advertise<type>(topicBase + "/velocity");

You could create individual string for each topic, or redo the string math a publish time. However, this adds more code, feels like a limitation, and makes it relatively easy for people to do bad things (such as accidentally alter a string).

So, my proposed solution is to return an object from Node::Advertise that essentially encapsulates the topic string. A user can't change the topic name, and this feels a bit better to me.

The string based method has not been lost.

New usage:

auto pubId = node.Advertise<type>("topicName");
node.Publish(pubId, msg);

// pubId also acts a boolean, so you can still do the following
if (!node.Advertise<type>("topicName"))
  cerr << "Some badness\n";

node.Publish("topicName", msg);

values.description:
Adding the ability to publish a message using the `ign` command line tool.

Example usage that publishes a string message on the `/foo` topic with data="Hello"

```
ign topic -t /foo -m ign_msgs.StringMsg -p 'data: "Hello"'
```

Run the `examples/subscriber` with the above command to test.

Other changes:

1. Changed `IGNITION_VISIBLE` to `IGNITION_TRANSPORT_VISIBLE` to avoid naming conflicts with other ignition libraries.
1. Removed all internal protobuf messages, and instead transport now depends on ignition-msgs.

values.description:
A better design for the discovery class:

* Instead of having two variants per function (e.g.: `AdvertiseMsg()`, `AdvertiseSrv()`), we now have only one variant (`Advertise()`, `Subscribe()`, etc.). We now have two `Discovery` objects, one for topics and the other for services, operating on different ports.

* The `Discovery` class is templated now, so I removed `Discovery.cc` and `DiscoveryPrivate.cc`

* Instead of having three dedicated threads for each discovery object, there's now only one. It still works using a reactor pattern waiting in `poll()` until there's activity in the socket or other things to do. The timeout is now dynamic, to make sure that we leave `poll()` if we have to send a heartbeat or check the validity of the discovery information (which was previously performed in separate threads).

* I had to prefix `g_` to some global variables in test files to avoid warnings. I didn't rename all globals for not making this pull request even bigger. There's a bit of inconsistency in some global variables but I'll fix it in a separate pull request that will add `g_` prefix to all global variables.

* Added a few `const` to some functions.

* Remove `advertiseInterval` member variable and its accessors. It was unused.

Sorry for the size of this PR.

CI results:

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any/14/) :large_blue_circle: 
* [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/103/) :large_blue_circle: 
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/207/) :large_orange_diamond: It seems there's an unrelated problem on Jenkins. All tests passed on my local VM.

values.description:
See [issue #1976](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/1976/) from the Gazebo issue tracker.

The problem was located in the `NodeShared` class destructor. After the destruction of the ZMQ sockets and before the destruction of the Discovery object, a callback in the Discovery was executed and propagated to the `NodeShared` class with the ZMQ sockets in `NodeShared` already deallocated from memory.

This PR reallocates the member variables in `NodeShared` and removes the explicit call to `Reset` in the destructor.

CI results:

* [Trusty](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any/20/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/110/) :large_blue_circle:
* [Windows](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/ignition/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/228/) :large_blue_circle:

values.description:
We want to restrict the maximum topic length. Right now, the topic length field is a ```uint64_t```, allowing a really huge string with its potential security risks. We can change ```uint64_t``` to a ```uint16_t```. On the one hand, ```uint16_t``` is not very big and it forbids to have very long topic. On other hand, ```uint16_t``` is not very small and it allows to have enough space for any potential topic value.

* Changing ```uint64_t``` to a ```uint16_t```.
* Adding tests for ```Publisher::MsgLength()``` method.
* Updating ```Discovery.hh::kWireVersion```.
* Adding ```TopicUtils::kMaxNameLength = 65535```. The ```kMaxNameLength``` specifies the maximum number of characters allowed in a namespace, a partition name, a topic name, and a fully qualified topic name.
* Minor edits in error messages (```Topic``` -> ```Service```).

values.description:
When a test fails to run in jenkins, it doesn't have the name of the test displayed in the test results page:

* http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_transport-ci-pr_any-windows7-amd64/254/testReport/

This updates the check_test_ran.py script to use the test file name in the junit classname, so that jenkins can differentiate between tests that failed to run and you don't have to look at the console output.

It also adds a fix to output a new junit file if a junit file exists but is empty. I copied these changes from gazebo.
